pullRequest.title: Create/update SavingYourWork and DataManagement
pullRequest.bodyText: Part of on-going discussion in jmri-developers.  Not yet linked for general consumption.

commit.message:
Update and rename SaveWhatHowWhereWhen.shtml to DataManagement.shtml

Still testing, not linked for general consumption.

Create StoringYourWork.shtml

For testing, part of on-going discussion in jmri-developers group.  Not linked for general consumption.

Update DataManagement.shtml

Include new sidebar for testing

Update StoringYourWork.shtml

Include new sidebar for testing.

nodes.bodyText: "JMRI is meant to have a simple model for handing the information it needs to do its various functions. Certain kinds of data are handled automatically.  For other kinds, were you might want to decide whether or not to change the data that's kept from one run of JMRI to the next, we provide options that let you control that by function.  For example, saving changes to roster entries is separate from deciding to store away the entire layout configuration".  There's nothing unfortunate about this at all.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,185 @@ + + + + + + JMRI: Storing Your Work + + + + + + + + +
+ +
+ + +

JMRI: Storing Your Work

+

What Everyone Should Know

+ +

This page provides the basic informaiton you should know about what commands are used to store the + data you create and update in JMRI. A companion page with more information for advanced users about when, how, and where JMRI + stores data is available here.

+ +

As you work with JMRI, you will create and update many different items within its various applications and tools. + You may also develop and run "scripts" that will do that as well. JMRI may also update some of this data during train operaton. + To ensure that data you create (or is created and updated for you) is stored for your future use, you need to know when different + things get saved to a disk file (and, in the case of CVs, to your locomotives and other DCC decoders) so that they will be there + when you next enter JMRI. There are also a few things that are saved automatically by JMRI, and some that are not saved at all + after you quit.

+ +
    +
  • User initiated
    • +
  • Automatic
    • +
  • Not stored
    • +
+ + + +

Things you need to "store" or "save"

+ +
+ +

Unfortunately, there is no single command to store all user created or modified data, and JMRI does not always notify you if there
